ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
CHARGING METHOD FOR MOBILE PHONE USERS
(Switch from Mobile-Party-Pays to Calling-Party-Pays)


    1. Mr Tan Soo Khoon asked the Acting Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts if the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore will make a decision soon on whether to switch from the existing Mobile-Party-Pays (MPP) charging method to the Calling-Party-Pays (CPP) charging method for mobile phone users.

    The Acting Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (Mr David T. E. Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, IDA is now examining the pros and cons of mandating that mobile operators switch from a Mobile-Party-Pays (MPP) charging method to the Calling-Party-Pays (CPP) regime. Moving to the CPP system may lower mobile rates. But, on the other hand, fixed line users may have to pay more for calls between fixed-line and mobile users.

    Deciding which system benefits users more is a complex issue. MITA is therefore conducting a detailed economic analysis

Column: 1827

to examine, among other things, the capital and operating costs involved in implementing the change from MPP to CPP, how the CPP charging system could impact prices that consumers pay, the system of inter-operator network charges for both fixed and mobile operators, and consumer and industry behaviour arising from such a change. We expect to reach a decision by the fourth quarter of this year.

    Mandating a change in the charging method is a serious matter, because it would have a major impact on both industry and consumers. This was why IDA had, earlier this year, conducted a public consultation to seek views on the two charging regimes. However, only two consumers had responded to the public consultation. IDA is, therefore, conducting a consumer survey to obtain more comprehensive feedback directly from mobile phone users, in order to complement the views obtained from industry in the public consultation. IDA will incorporate the survey results and consumer views into its study.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): Sir, I am sure the Minister is aware that most countries have already opted for the CPP system. Although he has stated that the fixed line callers may end up paying more, is he aware that the experience in other countries is that, under the CPP system, operators would actually come out with a great variety of charging plans and thereby offering consumers greater choice, which in the end actually results in lower prices?

    Mr David Lim: Sir, indeed, a number of other countries have adopted the CPP system. In Singapore, the adoption of MPP has not hindered the growth of the industry. In fact, we have one of the highest rates of mobile phone usage in Singapore. Our penetration rate is higher than 70%. I think the latest figure shows that it is about 71%. So this has not hindered the growth of the industry. But for the reasons I cited earlier, switching from one system to the other does have implications for the marketplace. So we want to take time to study this issue carefully.

    Question again proposed.



    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Thank you, Sir, for allowing me to continue. Yesterday, I started my speech and gave my impression that while the streaming system was intended to allow each child to learn and progress at his or her own pace, the problem seems to be in implementing the system. For many reasons, including the pressure of the school ranking system, schools and principals end up putting their best resources to focus on the EM1 and EM2 streams, or the best streams in the school system, so that the overall grades of the school look good. The end effect has been detrimental, both in terms of the failure to let late bloomers bloom at all, and in terms of destroying the self-esteem of our children at such a young age by putting labels on them. The Minister's argument has been that the streaming system has prevented wastage and resulted in very few children dropping out of the school system.

    I would like to suggest to the Minister that he would still achieve no dropouts from the education system if he allows every child to be streamed at the Primary 6 level, after the PSLE examinations. There are many ways to skin a cat - to borrow a phrase from the Malaysians - and one of them in the education system is to categorise our children after the PSLE examinations, a bit later, and send weaker children to technical schools to pursue a different route. This one change of streaming children from Primary 4 to Primary 6 level will satisfy many

Column: 1829

Singaporeans who have a major issue with the current system.

    The issues I would like the Minister to address are, firstly, are there any scientific reasons for continuously streaming our children at Primary 2, Primary 4, Primary 6 and Secondary 2 levels? Children are moved every two years depending on their academic results. From what I understand, the selection of the Primary 4 level was an arbitrary decision for lack of scientific information, when the then Education Minister, Dr Goh Keng Swee, made the decision on the streaming system. The issues with continuous streaming are: How do we teach children about friendships, building bonds and to help those who have different ability levels compared to themselves when they are moved constantly?

    Secondly, can the Ministry do a study on the attitudes of teachers and students towards EM3 students? While the intent of streaming is to allow them to progress at different levels, the real practice is that teachers dread taking EM3 classes when, in fact, they should see it as a challenge. The very fact that this happens means that the system has not been able to achieve very good EM3 to EM2 crossovers. Can the Minister share with the House on the success rate of such crossovers?

    Thirdly, does the Ministry have a performance target as to how many crossovers it hopes to achieve every year? Lack of such performance measures means that there is a lack of interest to see many more EM3 students making it back to the higher streams.

    If the Ministry wants to take a conservative approach to changing the system, can we implement a hybrid system where children are kept in the same class and share a common curriculum for most of their contact time, and then break up for specific areas to focus, for children of different abilities? Perhaps we can choose a few schools with good PSLE track records to experiment with the hybrid system.

    Sir, recently, in the USA, a new law was passed, called the "No Child Left Behind

Column: 1830

Act" (NCLB Act of 2002). This Act, among other things, places important priority on targeting assistance to society's most disadvantaged students in the hope of closing the learning divide once and for all. A learning divide is what our education system is creating in Singapore, in my opinion.

    I feel that this is such an important issue that we perhaps need a whole day session to debate this issue. If I ask the MPs here to put up their hands as to whether they agree - I would not try it - I think many would not. I have spoken to many teachers and principals. Many of them do not agree with this system too, although they are afraid to speak up. Most Singaporeans do not agree with the streaming system, as it is. I hope some changes will be made.

    Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): Sir, this year, the Education Ministry has been allocated the second highest budget. In fact, a total of $6.79 billion has been allocated to the Education Ministry, which is higher than the amount allocated in FY2001. This is a strong indication of the Government's commitment to human capital development. There is no doubt that we have a good education system supported by a dedicated teaching staff and a population that places a high premium on education as a means to uplift itself. But then, Sir, no system is perfect, and a responsive and adaptable system must take into account the changing needs and concerns of those that it is designed to serve. It is in this light that one has to view this on-going debate on streaming. It is not an indictment of the whole system, as our overall educational framework is sound. But some policies clearly need some tweaking as we move along.

    What are the desired outcomes of the education system, one may ask? As many see it today, it is to feed the labour market and ensure that everyone has the skill to find a job. There is nothing wrong with this and, in fact, it is something which is very necessary if we do not want to have social problems. Take the example of Malaysia, for instance, where there

Column: 1831

are university graduates with irrelevant degrees and hence they cannot find jobs. But, then, at the same time, there is also nothing wrong to expect our education system to produce balanced individuals who love education and learning for the sake of itself and who are capable of independent thinking, not mere rote learners, and who are very strongly rooted in our values as a society. The education system must also provide a process of learning that is enjoyable and fun.

    Sir, I am sure that many of us remember our own childhood days with fond memories, the simple joys and abandonment of growing up. But what about our children? What do they remember about their childhood - examinations, assessment books, supplementary classes and tuition classes? Is it right, one may ask, to put so much pressure on our children at such a young age? This is precisely what happens with streaming. Within a period of six years that he is in primary school, a child will have to go through two major examinations - one when he is streamed at Primary 4 and the other when he sits for the PSLE - and the two examinations are very close to each other. After a child has finished mugging for the streaming examinations, he has to immediately start ramming up in Primary 5 in preparation for the PSLE. Small wonder then that in a survey of 1,742 children aged 10 and 12, commissioned by SPH last year, students said that they were more afraid of examinations than of their parents dying.

    Sir, we also have to ask the question whether it is realistic for us to assess a child's capabilities and later stream him based only on the examination results, which actually measure performance over a very short period of two hours for each subject. Based on this, we then decide that the child should go to the fast, the average or the slow-learning track. Many experts in education are in agreement that at the age of 10 years, a child's cognitive skills are not fully developed yet. So, is it reasonable to start streaming our children at this age?

Column: 1832



    Sir, of very great concern to parents is the negative effect of labelling - EM1, EM2 and EM2, slightly better than the old system of classifying children as being in the Normal, Express or Monolingual streams. But, nevertheless, it is still streaming. In those days, if you were a "Mono", then you are in deep trouble. People look at you in a certain way as if you are a moron or doomed forever. Although the labels have changed, the implications of this labelling process remain. If you are in EM1, you are first class; EM2, second class; and EM3, sad to say, you are in third class. What is worse is that this labelling could by itself be a self-fulfilling prophecy. Instead of spurring children to greater heights, those labelled EM3 could very well say that they are useless and a failure, and nothing that they do can change the situation.

    Sir, is it fair, reasonable and justifiable to label children at such a young age, and thereby sowing the seeds of elitism and segmentation right from primary school? Have we ever considered the impact and damage that such a system will have on our children's self-esteem and self-confidence, when they are in their crucial years of self-discovery and are in the process of developing emotional and social anchors to guide them as they grow into adults?

    Sir, I would therefore like to join my other colleagues, who have spoken before me, to ask the Ministry to revisit the streaming policy. Please consider doing away with streaming at Primary 4. The children's examination results at PSLE are, in my view, sufficient for assessing our children's capabilities and to stream them according to their results. Alternatively, if this is not possible ---

    The Chairman: 30 seconds, Mdm Halimah.

    Mdm Halimah Yacob: Sir, I am finishing. Alternatively, Sir, if this is not possible, I would like to ask the Minister to consider allowing some schools or classes not to have streaming. I would also like to ask the Minister to do away with the first class, second class and third class labels

Column: 1833

of EM1, EM2 and EM3. It has very serious negative connotations and I am not convinced, just like many parents, that it is good for our society in the long run.

    Dr Ong Seh Hong (Aljunied): Sir, I agree with the objective of streaming if it is to maximise the potential and ability of each individual, develop his or her special talents and minimise wastage of our education system. However, I echo the concerns of my hon. colleagues, Mdm Halimah and Mr Inderjit Singh, on the shortfall of our current streaming system. As I see it, there are some areas of our current streaming system that must be addressed before we can really achieve the objective we set out to do.
12.45 pm

    First, streaming at Primary 4 is too early, as children at this age are not fully developed psychologically or connectively. And this is the point that I alluded to during the debate on the President's Address, and Mdm Halimah has also just reiterated the point.

    Secondly, streaming uses only academic results as the only criteria. This fails to recognise other types of talents in areas such as sports, arts and music. If we do not recognise these talents, how can we maximise and develop them? Is there any surprise that we have not much luck in achieving sports excellence?

    Thirdly, using academic criteria alone will also result in a kiasu examination-oriented mentality, and defeats the true purpose of education. It makes study and examination a source of stress, just as Mdm Halimah quoted the SPH survey in 2000, that students were more afraid of examinations and tests than of their parents dying. I would be very sad if, one day, my daughter comes and tells me, "Dad, I would rather you die than I fail the examination." Maybe, at that point of time, I would choose to die!

    Fourthly, the present system does not address the need of various groups of

Column: 1834

students who do not do well at their streaming examination. Under the current system, if a student does not do well in the examination, he is in EM3. That is it! However, we must know that children may have done poorly for a variety of reasons, other than being a slow learner or of lower IQ. First, there may be a group of students who are socially disadvantaged, such as those who come from broken families. This group of children would need social intervention to help them, and not a placement in EM3. The next group of students, who may not do well, are those who may have learning disabilities, such as dyslexia, and, again, they need special education and not EM3. The third group may be those who have just bad luck. This poor kid may be too nervous and did not do well in the examination, or his parents might be quarrelling the night before, therefore affecting his mental readiness for examination. This group of children need a second chance to sit for the examination, and not a placement in EM3 that labels him permanently. Therefore, may I urge the Minister to review the age of streaming, and maybe do it at a much later age.

    The Ministry should also put in extra efforts to identify the underlying causes of students who do not do well in the streaming - I have stated earlier the reasons for not doing well - and help them accordingly. Sir, I also urge the Minister to put in appropriate measures to spot and develop talents in non-academic fields.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, as I have anticipated, what I wish to say in this House has already been the subject of much passionate debate. But the subject of streaming continues to be a cause of so much anguish that I feel it would be morally irresponsible for me not to speak up, at the risk of repeating what my colleagues have said.

    Let me state, at the outset, that I think, overall, we do have a good education system, one that is efficient and focused. And it has succeeded in producing many generations of skilled workers to support our economic thrusts. It has

Column: 1835

placed Singapore on the world map as a leader in Mathematics and Science education and the application of IT to learning. It has grounded generations of school children in the realities and the joys of multi-racialism and harmonious communal living.

    Since 2000, the direction has been towards an ability-driven education to develop and harness the talents of our students. But while a differentiated curriculum for students to suit differing aptitudes is administratively efficient, the question arises whether the gains to the nation from such efficiency is outweighed by the psychological cost this has inflicted on Primary 4 10-year olds and their long suffering parents.

    But we must first give credit where it is due. I know of a Singaporean mother who has just come back from Germany for her son's education because she feels that the system in Germany is the other extreme - too relaxed, no home work, everything at one's pace, but usually pegged at the speed of the slowest child. Sir, I submit this is not the outcome I welcome, as soon, we, as a nation, may lose our drive and competitive spirit and that is the sure road to perdition.

    But, Sir, there is a yawning gap between parents and the MOE for all its good and noble intentions. I believe many in this House have school-going children, or have interacted with other parents, and therefore will understand where the stress point lies. At a recent feedback session on Education, the subject that occupied the most time and electrified the atmosphere was, as Members will have guessed it, streaming. One participant even objected to the term "gifted children". She asked what does that imply about the other children. Does this mean that they are not gifted?

    Parents say streaming is bad for the following reasons: streaming, particularly at the young age of 10 years - Primary 4 - prematurely labels a child as slow, a no-hope case and affects his self-esteem.

Column: 1836

It demoralises the child and may make it difficult for him to return to mainstream education later on in Express or Normal (Academic) stream. It disadvantages late bloomers, causing him to lose opportunities and also causing the system to lose what may have turned out to be a brilliant scientist or entrepreneur. Einstein, it has been frequently pointed out, was not exactly a top student in school.

    Nonetheless, MOE is strongly convinced that streaming is good for the following reasons: streaming allows our children to learn at their own pace, and not suffer unnecessary performance-related stress. The alternative to streaming, to quote the Minister for Education from the Budget 2001 Committee of Supply debate, is that many children will fail and they will drop out of school. No doubt, MOE will again furnish more and updated statistics this time to show the benefits of streaming.

    Sir, I am persuaded that there are merits to both sets of arguments. However, I strongly feel that it is time to refine the system, to close this gap between parents and MOE. This is especially critical when we are committed to maximising the potential of every Singaporean and trying to nurture an entrepreneurial spirit in our young. We should not disillusion them by labelling them as no-hope cases at such a young age. As noted by the Prime Minister, "Morale is a very important thing. If we feel demoralised, then we are not in the mood to fight competitively."

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister if there are plans to review and modify the current system to mitigate some of these concerns. For a start, may I suggest that the Ministry assure parents that as much attention, if not more, is focused on these "laggard" children to develop their potential as for the other cohorts. The successes of these children should be celebrated as much, if not more than the others, so that parents' concerns are mitigated and children assured that there are many roads to success.

    Sir, like my parliamentary colleagues before me, I would like to urge the Ministry to heed the call to send all cows

Column: 1837

to the vets, for surely this cow needs a thorough check-up and medication, if not a worse fate.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, with the world changing at a fast pace to one that requires future generations to have critical, creative and innovative minds, there is indeed a danger of our young getting lost in our nation building process. I therefore believe it is timely now that the Ministry of Education review the streaming system. There are side effects about streaming of students under the current education system.

    First of all, by categorising our young into academically enumerated groupings, this reinforces the view that only children who are academically intelligent are valuable and relevant assets of the future. Those individuals who are talented in other aspects, be it in sports or music, etc, seem to have no niche in this streaming system. Although the recent announcement of setting up of the speciality school can address these problems somewhat, I am of the view that the streaming system should be changed to better reflect the emphasis on individual capability and talent in areas other than just academia.

    Secondly, nation building means coagulating a diverse population into one entity. The streaming system does not encourage the recognition and toleration of diversity in terms of talents and capabilities. The streaming system suggests that we are judged purely in terms of academic performance. In other words, only the academically sound are deemed working to be our best pillars of tomorrow. Of course, not all those in the best stream eventually become leaders, and neither will those in the lower stream fall by the wayside. But, as a general trend, what I have suggested - that the system has inculcated important values which, I emphasise again, are academic capabilities - is valid.

    Thirdly, Sir, although the purpose of streaming is to help an individual student to develop his or her potential to the fullest, by being able to study in his or

Column: 1838

her own pace, the question is whether streaming itself is effective enough to develop a child's potential. Earlier, I have mentioned that streaming will reinforce academic ability as the only criterion for judging students. However, the question is: what exactly constitutes academic ability? Some children are better with their mathematical understanding, some better with Science, and some are better with languages.

    The current streaming system streams in accordance with the cluster of subjects and determination of academic ability, in totality, in the cluster. Such a system fails to take into account the relative strengths and relative interests of each student based on the individual subjects. This is even more jarring at the Secondary 2 and Secondary 3 levels. For example, a non-Pure Science Express stream, or non-Express stream student, is likely to face a situation that his interest in reading individual Pure Science module, such as Biology, might be hampered as a result of the streaming. Also, for that matter, a Pure Science streamed student might never have the opportunity to pursue technical studies, or arts subject at the "O" level, as a result of the streaming. This is because the current streaming system assumes that students streamed to a particular stream are naturally more inclined to certain subjects offered.

    I would therefore ask the Ministry to consider exploring the idea of organising schools based on subjects. This means scrapping the current streaming system based on a cluster of subjects and replacing it with a system based on subjects. Students would be grouped into different classes based on the merit of their individual subject. Although it could be argued that this is still a form of streaming, I am sure such a system of allowing individual students to learn at their own pace is more progressive and is likely to lessen social stigma. This is not to say that schools are to abandon the idea of all-rounded education, but rather the main thrust of the proposal here is the acceptance of the fact that different students have different strengths. Hence, there must be avenues, opportunities and

Column: 1839

recognition available to allow individual student to "major" in what he or she loves. To allow the above to be implemented, there must be a total revamp, in terms of entire education process, such as grading, protocol, examination systems, admission requirements, etc, to support the new education system paradigm. I do not have specific recommendations for the various components, which require further in-depth studies and analysis for more details.
1.00 pm

    Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Sir, I support the principle of streaming in schools, ie, allowing children to study at their own pace and capabilities. However, I would like to appeal to the Ministry to look at the parents' concern. Streaming is not only at Primary 4. I see streaming is done at every year of study. At Primary 5, if a student does not do well, he will have to slide down to EM2 or EM3. This is similarly done in Secondary 1, Secondary 2 and Secondary 3. If the students do not do well, they slide down to the Normal stream. Why do we need to do streaming each year? I would like to propose to do away with streaming at each year as, in the present system, the students are already streamed and their capability of study at certain intervals, after Primary 6 and at Secondary 4. The two stages at Primary 4 and Secondary 2 should just be subject combinations based on the language capability and interest of each child. Remove the threat that goes with each student the possibility of sliding down to the lower stream at each year. We should allow a more flexible stream, give more space and time for the children and the parents in between the years, ie, before the major examinations of PSLE and GCE 'O' Level, to explore and have fun in their studies.

    I have included the parents, as I know most parents are studying alongside with their children in Singapore. I did another Primary 6 three years ago. The rush by parents to apply for annual leave

Column: 1840

    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): First, let me thank Members for contributing their views and suggestions to improve our education system. Allow me to start with a broad overview of the progress we have made, and where we are headed, in order to place this discussion on education within the larger context of what we are working to achieve.

    Much has been done over the last five years. We have moved the school system forward in a number of critical areas, including major enhancements to the teaching service through EduPac, trimming the curriculum to allow more time to develop creativity and thinking skills, strengthening citizenship and values education, devolving more authority and responsibility to schools and school clusters, renewing our school buildings, and introducing IT into all our schools.

    Mr Magad has just asked for an update on the IT Masterplan. The Ministry is completing its evaluation on the current

Column: 1851

Masterplan which is nearing completion - it has been 5-6 years - and will unveil its second IT Masterplan for the period 2003-2007 in a few months' time. So, I request Mr Magad to be just a little patient. When we wrap it all up, we will give him a full report.

    Sir, we have made much progress, but the Ministry of Education is not resting on its laurels, and I am sure Members of this House would not allow the Ministry of Education to do so. Dr Wang has suggested that the Ministry should leave no stone unturned. Indeed, the previous improvements I have enumerated have merely been made within the existing structure of the education system. And going forward, our emphasis would be on structural issues. We will look at what structures in the education system may need to be changed. The major thrusts in the coming years would be, first, the review of the upper secondary and junior college sector; and second, the restructuring of the university sector.

    We will consider a new JC curriculum, better integrated upper secondary and JC programmes, alternative qualifications, and private schools at the secondary and JC levels. We will also consider specialised schools in Science and Mathematics, and in the arts, like the sports school, which will cater to students with different aptitudes and interest, as Mr Low desires. At the tertiary level, the upgrading of the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts and the La Salle-SIA College of the Arts, funded by the Ministry of Education, as well as the establishment of the Music Conservatory in NUS will provide more opportunities for those with the talent and interest in these areas. The polytechnics and ITE will continue to expand, and we will also provide more university places in the relevant fields, and also possibly allow private universities to be established.

    Taken together, these initiatives will provide more opportunities and options to our students at the upper secondary and tertiary levels, building on a very strong

Column: 1852

foundation which we have today, providing a good solid basic education to our children in our primary and secondary schools.

    Let me now address some of the specific issues that Members have raised. First, streaming. First of all, I would like to thank Members for agreeing with the principle of streaming. Streaming provides opportunities for educational advancement to all students according to their aptitudes and abilities. It is not that we have not tried a system without streaming before. That was a system I grew up in, and also many of the Members of this House. But that left many members of our society by the wayside, and that is why we have, today, such a large problem in the age group, 40-50, who have not completed their secondary education.

    Our streaming differentiates curriculum and the pace and method of learning, so that each student can proceed at his or her own pace and gain a sense of achievement and motivation to learn. Members have emphasised the need for the education system to maximise the potential of our students. This is precisely what streaming attempts to do. This is the strength our system has, and is a major reason for the high achievement levels of our students.

    The alternative to streaming is mixed ability classes, where teaching has to be targeted at the average. In such classes, the more academically able will languish as they lose interest in the curriculum, while the less academically able students give up, as they cannot keep pace with the curriculum. This was what we found previously before streaming was introduced. There is a tendency for us to look back in history with rose tinted glasses. We should take an objective look and see whether we are doing better for the broad majority of our students today than we did in the past.

    Mdm Halimah has asked how we address the issue of school dropouts. We do so by trying to make sure that as few of them do so as possible in the first place.

Column: 1853

Through streaming and giving those who need it a lighter curriculum or more time, we have reduced educational wastage and successfully raised the educational attainment of our students. In 1980, before streaming was introduced, only 58% of our Primary 1 cohort completed secondary school. By last year, the proportion had gone up to 93%. This is because we have been able to provide a differentiated curriculum for the students. Through streaming, we have, therefore, been able to sharply reduce dropout rates due to educational reasons. Students may still drop out for a variety of personal, family or social reasons. To address this, we work with the VWOs and MCDS.
1.30 pm

    Perhaps the best indicator of the success of streaming is how well it has served our less academically inclined students. Prior to the streaming system, and the articulation of the EM3, normal technical stream and ITE, we really had very few educational opportunities for students like these. They would drop out of school and enter the workforce with no specific skills.

    In 1994, we introduced the Normal (Technical) course in secondary schools. These students did not use to go to secondary schools. They would go to primary school, spend a few extra years in primary schools as over-sized students, and then go on to VITB. Those pupils who will do better in a practical rather than academic setting, who previously went to VITB after Primary 6, now have a chance to shoot for secondary education, to develop the foundation for acquiring a higher level of skills at the post-secondary level. Simultaneously, we upgraded the VITB and restructured it to become a post-secondary institution, the ITE, to provide such students with further post-secondary opportunities for education. This has lifted the level of these students. With the expansion of places at junior colleges, polytechnics and ITEs, 8 out of 10 of our students now go on to post-secondary education compared to 1 out of 10 in those rosy days of 1965. This percentage is at least as high, if not higher

Column: 1854

than even those achieved by the most developed countries today.

    Mdm Halimah asked how our less academically inclined students do after they leave school. They do very well. ITE graduates are sought after by employers who pay them very well. Even in the midst of the recession last year, 88% of ITE graduates found employment within three months of graduation. In comparison, there were university graduates who were still looking for jobs after half a year. In particular, the average monthly salary for fresh ITE graduates range from $1,100-$1,400 a month. This compares well with fresh polytechnic graduates, whose monthly salary ranges from $1,500-$1,900 a month.

    Mr Singh, Mdm Halimah and others, said that streaming is done too early. Dr Ong asked if streaming could be done later to take into account late-developers. Sir, it is precisely because we have late-developers that we need streaming. Otherwise, what do we do with the late-developers? Whatever the reason for their poorer academic performance at that point in time, forcing them to learn at a pace that they cannot or are not ready to cope with will simply push them out of the system. Streaming allows them to continue to learn at a pace comfortable to them.

    Even after students enter a particular stream, there is a well-structured progression route for them through to post-secondary education, and a net of "ladders and bridges", that allows students to go as far as they can, and even across streams. It is wrong to say that our education system provides no chance for late bloomers. It is our previous system, before streaming, that did not provide chances for late bloomers. That, as I said, is a major reason why so many of our 40 and 50-year olds today, people who went to school with you and me, have not completed secondary education. They had no opportunities and, after failing, staying back a few years, they left school, without any specific qualification or skill. In contrast, our system now provides students of all abilities, the opportunity to

Column: 1855

get a solid foundation of at least 10 years of primary and secondary education, with 8 out of 10 of them, going beyond that, to further education.

    Late-developers still have opportunities for self-improvement. Those who do well, and can benefit from going on with their education, can do so. Every year, about 1,000 ITE graduates go on to the polytechnics, and 1,000 polytechnic graduates go on to our universities. Without streaming, late-developers would have been nipped in the bud instead.

    I had a discussion with polytechnic students at a Poly Seminar three years ago. One student stood up and lamented that the system did not provide second chances. It turned out that he was 29 years old, and in the Polytechnic. He was in the process of getting his second chance. Last year, the Lee Kuan Yew Award winner in the ITE was a not so young man, called Simon Foo, from the Navy, I am proud to add. He was the top graduate of ITE for the year, and has been offered a place to study in the polytechnic. He is now 27 years old and married. Without the Normal programme and the ITE, he might never have qualified to go to the polytechnic.

    Sir, the oldest student doing a full-time diploma in our polytechnics is now 50 years old. The oldest doing a part-time diploma is 68 years old. The ITE is the biggest provider of continuing education programmes in Singapore, with 34,000 students enrolled, and another 20,000 on ITE accredited courses conducted by industry training partners. We should applaud the chances and opportunities that ITE is, in fact, giving to many of our students, to many of our mature Singaporeans, opportunities which they might not otherwise have got.

    Finally, a word on streaming. It is important to note that for streaming in schools, at primary level, there is a parental option when students are streamed at the end of Primary 4. Parents have the final say. Parents can choose not

Column: 1856

to put their child in the EM3 stream at Primary 5, or if they feel that they are too stressed, they can choose not to put their children in EM1. But very few parents opt their children out of EM1 and many parents opt their children from EM2 to EM1.

    Mr Singh suggested that we have a hybrid system where children are kept in the same class in primary school, and break up for specific subjects to cater for children of differing abilities. The idea is not a bad one. The issue is one of practicality - whether it will, in practice, achieve the objectives that Mr Singh has stated. In the primary schools, there are basically 4 subjects being taught, mother tongue being one of them, with the children already split up. This means that if we split up children for other subjects, they would be breaking out of their classes, perhaps 75-100% of their time. This would have implications on resources, time-tabling, etc, and, of course, it will mean that the children do not get to spend most of their time together and just split up for some lessons, which is what Mr Singh's objective was. However, if schools wish to pilot or try this out, I have no objection to them trying.

    Mr Singh also said that students of different abilities should interact with each other, and I agree that this is important. Students have opportunities to build bonds and friendships outside their classrooms. For instance, CCAs provide avenues for students from different backgrounds to engage in the same activities. The drum-major in the band, the basket ball captain, or the star in the football team may not come from the fastest stream in the school. And they learn to work together and appreciate each other's strengths and weaknesses. It does not have to be, as Members of the House say, only in academic activities. And, in the process, they get to know each other better and learn to support each other in common endeavours. I should add that it is because we have streaming that we pick students from three different queues to enter the same schools, that we have good mixing in our secondary schools. If we did not

Column: 1857

have streaming, and students were posted to schools based on one linear list, based on their PSLE t-scores, then all the academically weakest students would probably be grouped in, say, 20 or so schools, rather than distributed among more than 120 secondary schools with students from other streams.

    Dr Khor mentioned that streaming is unpopular among teachers. I have frank discussions with teachers and principals regularly, several times a month, either during school visits or in dialogue sessions at the Ministry of Education headquarters, in groups of a dozen or so teachers. Teachers generally recognise children learn at different paces, and that it is not helpful for children to be given a curriculum that they cannot cope with. They are supportive of a stream, like the EM3, that caters for slower learners. Contrary to what Mr Singh says, they also do not dread taking on EM3 classes. Some of our most highly motivated teachers derive great satisfaction, and a sense of mission, from teaching less able kids. I think Dr Wang may well have interviewed some of them for the Outstanding Teacher and President's Teacher Awards. But they, like my colleagues in this House, do feel for these kids, and wonder how best to help the kids cope with the issues of labelling and stigmatisation, and to help them build up their self-esteem.

    These concerns have been expressed by Dr Khor and Mr Singh. Such labelling is really a social phenomenon. From a purely educational standpoint, I think Members in this House would agree, that streaming is the correct approach, as it tries to maximise the potential of all students by providing them with programmes as well suited to the students as possible, so that as many of them as possible can be successful in their own right. I am not sure really which is more damaging to self-esteem - to consistently fail because the curriculum and pace is so fast, or to perform comfortably well, achieve success in small bites every year, make steady progress in a less demanding stream, and eventually attain a qualification that employers attach value to.

Column: 1858



    The Ministry has consistently sought to lift the level of all our students. Members, like Dr Ong and Mr Singh, have suggested that there should be additional support for weaker students, and this is being done. At the primary school level, the Ministry has a Learning Support Programme (LSP) and the Encouraging Achievement and Better Learning (ENABLE) programme to give additional support to pupils who are weak in literacy or numeracy skills. At the secondary level, the Normal (Technical) students were among the first to have access to computers in their schools, before students from any other streams, when computer laboratories were specially set up for the teaching of Normal (Technical) subject Computer Applications. At the post-secondary level, the Ministry has devoted great efforts to upgrade technical education. Sir, this is a segment of our education system that I am particularly proud of. Some Members of this House were able to accept my invitation to visit the ITE, after the debate on the President's Address, and I would like to extend an open invitation to other Members of this House, to see ITE for themselves, and how well the students are doing. Come and have a look.

    Sir, I have visited many countries in the past five years, basically to study their education systems, to see how we can adapt the good things that they have done, to our system. They all have to deal with the issue of how to cater to the different educational needs of the whole spectrum of students.

    The Singapore education system does this better than most. And what is the evidence? In the Third International Mathematics and Science Study (1999), 93% and 80% of our secondary 2 students were above the international average for Mathematics and Science, respectively, for students of that age group. Sir, I am not surprised that the US needs to come up with new initiatives like the one that Mr Inderjit Singh pointed out, because a large proportion of their students fall well behind.

    The advantage of a good solid foundation carried through into post-secondary

Column: 1859

education, which benefits 8 out of 10 of our children, provides them further opportunities in life. And it places a vast majority of our students on the correct side of the knowledge divide that divides this world into the knowledge haves and the knowledge have-nots. And our education system has been able to provide a vast majority of Singaporeans with that leg up for the future, in engineering, bio-sciences and information technology, not just in the universities, but in the polytechnics and in the ITEs.

    Sir, ultimately, it is better to recognise that different students have different needs, and to explicitly provide different streams and educational opportunities for them, than to work on the premise, the hope, that they are all the same and fail to provide for their different needs, or provide for them in an ad hoc way, and then lament later when they do not make it.

    Parents and schools need to work together so that educational features like streaming and other forms of additional support that are meant to help pupils, do not become a cause of stigmatisation. Ironically, people who oppose streaming are often the same ones who perpetuate the labelling of our students - I do not call them failures, and I am not so sure why so many Members do - by viewing the provision of a more moderately paced curriculum and a sound technical education for students as something desirable, and we can encourage them to achieve their potential. This attitude of labelling and calling them names is something which we should change, and not streaming. I welcome suggestions from Members on how we can encourage these students, and discourage labelling.
1.45 pm

    Dr Wang suggested that we should also review school ranking. The introduction of school ranking has had a salutary effect on our schools. It has raised standards and allowed parents to make more informed choices, especially as to which

Column: 1860

are value-added schools. We only rank the top 50 secondary schools, and not all the secondary schools, nor do we rank the primary schools.

    Sir, school ranking is increasingly being adopted in the United States and in the UK, where often all the schools are ranked from top to bottom. And it is often in response to demands from parents to know how well schools are educating their children, because parents want to know. I have no doubt that if we did not have school ranking and did not provide information on how schools are doing, there will be parents who will ask us, and I think it is their right to know. There is nothing to hide.

    In the US and the UK, teachers do not like ranking - Dr Wang is quite right - because the teachers are now held accountable to standards when, previously, they were not. But should we hold our schools and teachers accountable for standards? I think the answer is yes. Sir, I am open to ideas on how ranking can be improved, and suggestions from Members of the House are welcome.

    Two years ago, I informed Members of this House that we introduced a new appraisal system called the School Excellence Model, where schools do self-evaluation on not just their outputs but also their internal processes. I have given out awards for Best Practice and Sustained Achievements since 1999, to recognise schools for a wide range of areas, from CCA to staff development. However, these awards have not attracted nearly as much attention from the public and the media as school ranking. But I do hope that, over time, the public will learn to recognise that a good school is more than just an absolute ranking, and consists of a whole host of other things.

    Mr Yeo has suggested that our system is too stressful and puts too much pressure on students. It is true that our students study hard in school, and that our schools seek to ensure that students do their best. However, the strong foundation that our Singapore children have acquired from the hard work that they put in, and the

Column: 1861

strong work ethic, are important qualities that will help them to succeed in life.

    Incidentally, Members who feel that our children are over loaded should be strong advocates of streaming, as it addresses precisely their concern by differentiating the pacing and content of curriculum according to ability. Mdm Halimah and others have said that children are more concerned about their examinations than they are about their parents dying. Frankly, Sir, I think we are fortunate to live in a country where children are focused on their studies and examinations, and not on their parents dying. I have no doubt that if we live in a war-torn country or a country which is rife with terrorism and so on, then children will be worried about their parents dying everyday, rather than their schools and examinations. I would not like to live in a country like that.

    The problem of excessive pressure arises when there is a mismatch between expectations and achievement. Schools, parents and society need to understand that while we want the best for our children, we should not push them beyond their limits. One example is streaming at Primary 4. There is really no point overloading children with higher mother tongue in EM1 if they are unable to cope. Yet, many parents opt in to EM1 stream for their children, and few opt out from it.

    The movie, I Not Stupid, reflected quite starkly how some Singaporeans have chosen parochial definitions of success and imposed them on their children. Mr Yeo mentioned a serious moment in the movie where one of the characters wanted to commit suicide. Sir, I happen to think that this is an excellent movie. It provides a mirror for our society and for each of us, and allows each of us to see how we might actually be behaving and how this behaviour may even, with the best of intentions, have a negative effect on our children and on others. It is a useful movie for principals, parents and teachers to watch. I should point out, though, that in the movie, the student wanted to commit suicide, not because he could not cope with his school work, but because he could not live up to his mother's unrealistic expectations that he attain more than

Column: 1862

90 marks in his test. We need a broader definition of success. Being all that we can be should be counted as success.

    When Mr Singh said that the Ministry should set performance targets on the number of lateral transfers from what he calls a lower stream to a higher stream, he is, in fact, narrowing the definition of what it means to be successful, to whether a student is able to move from EM3 to EM2. The Ministry does not have targets for lateral transfers, because setting such targets means that we will be forcing students to learn at a pace that they cannot cope with. This is not the best thing for them. This may result in pushing them out of the system. It is more meaningful to provide an appropriate programme with adequate and proper support to weaker students to maximise their potential and provide them with avenues of progression. EM3 students can progress through the system. Nobody has given up on them, and this has been our approach.

    On counselling, the Ministry has a programme for addressing the social and emotional needs of students. Counselling is available through the entire age range of students. All teachers are given basic training in counselling, and there are teacher counsellors of which there are two in each school, but they are part time. We also have trained some 30 retired education officers as counsellors. And by July this year, they will be deployed to schools and to clusters. But this is an area in which I will be the first to agree that we can do with more assistance. Schools work with VWOs, Family Service Centres and self-help groups. Incidentally, that is one of the reasons why since 1997-1998, the Ministry of Education, together with the Ministry of Health, has been promoting the support services such as those provided by the Institute of Mental Health, resulting in an increase in attendances.

    While schools provide support for the pupils, the support from home is of paramount importance in helping students to cope with stress, and when they face distress. Mr Gan suggested that there might also be a need to counsel parents.

Column: 1863

Yes, that is so, and where there is a need for parents to be counselled, I suggest that they be referred to Family Service Centres for the necessary support. The Ministry and our schools will be happy to work with other agencies and organisations on this issue, as it is an issue which the Ministry itself is not particularly well equipped to undertake.

    Sir, education seeks to provide Singaporeans with the opportunity to fulfil their potential. Because the potential of our students is multi-faceted, our education system has to provide opportunities to different programmes and different types of institutions. The way forward is to provide greater diversity in the school system and allowing for more educational routes and models, not just to consider one route or one model as the success paradigm, as many in this House seem to have the orientation towards. Such an approach will allow us to more fully develop the different abilities of our students.

    As mentioned earlier, the Ministry is currently carrying out a review of junior college and upper secondary education, and I will ask the Senior Minister of State, Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam, to update Members on that.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam): Sir, Dr Wang Kai Yuen has expressed views on the issues under MOE's review of the junior college and upper secondary education system. The Review Committee on JC and Upper Secondary Education, which comprises both educationists as well as people from the people sector, private sector and public sector and which I chair, is looking into two main areas. First, the principles and framework for a revised JC curriculum; and, second, the introduction of greater diversity of programmes within schools.

    The current JC curriculum has its strengths. The 'A' levels have served as the standard bearer for the rigour and

Column: 1864

high standards of our JC and pre-university education for the last 30 years. Over the years, we have continuously improved the JC curriculum, but the basic structure of the 'A' level programme is unchanged from the time we adopted it from the British. It is a system that was designed to provide students at age 17-18 with a strong core of knowledge in a few subjects - 3 or 4 subjects - to prepare them to enter the workplace. It also prepared students to go on to universities in the British mould - universities which require students to complete relatively specialised degrees within three years.

    The basic structure is one of specialisation at the 'A' levels after a broad secondary school education leading up to the 'O' levels. It is like the British system, but quite unlike that in the US and most of the European countries, where students undergo a broad-based curriculum throughout their school and pre-university years. Our universities have, however, departed from the British model. They offer 4-year degree programmes in many disciplines, and are now providing a broader education within the first and second years of university.

    Further, most students who are now sitting for the 'A' levels go on to university, unlike the situation 20-30 years ago. It is no longer a terminal qualification. Our 'A' level curriculum requires students to narrow their interest after the 'O' levels, before they broaden out again at university. Dr Wang Kai Yuen described the structure as having a Coca Cola bottle shape.

    We are reviewing the JC curriculum, not because it has worked badly, but because of the fundamentally different environment which young Singaporeans will have to engage in in future. We have transited to a knowledge-based economy. We have to prepare the young, as Dr Wang says, for uncertainty, in a rapidly changing environment. Flexibility, and an ability to understand and draw on different knowledge disciplines, will be at a premium.

    It will be difficult for students to know at age 17, or even when they are at

Column: 1865

university, what jobs they will do when they enter the workforce, or what new jobs they will take on over the course of their careers. Further, whatever profession they are in, they will have to pick up new knowledge and skills every so often, to stay on top of their jobs and to keep an edge over the competition. More of this knowledge will be drawn from the interconnections between disciplines. Many of the major breakthroughs in knowledge, and the economic opportunities that come with them, are coming out of the spaces between traditional subject disciplines.

    We have to prepare our young for this future. An example is bio-engineering, already an area of tremendous opportunity. To groom talent in bio-engineering, we ideally want engineers who know something about biology. But the current JC curriculum, like that in the UK, but unlike that in the United States, grooms future engineers who have no exposure to biology at the JC level, and often even earlier. Within the framework of four 'A' level subjects, those wanting to do engineering at university will typically take two mathematics subjects, physics and chemistry. There is no room to spare for biology. NUS and NTU are now remedying this by requiring engineering students to take biology during their first year at university. But the long-term solution is to give some of our future engineers exposure to biology at JC, without them giving up any of the other subjects that they wish to take. This is an example of why we need a broader and more flexible JC curriculum.

    A key part of the work of the Review Committee is public consultation. Over the past two months, we have had dialogue with various groups with a stake in education - parents, employers, entrepreneurs and professionals, academics, principals and teachers, and students themselves.

    There has been broad support in the public consultation on the need to broaden the JC curriculum, in a number of respects. First, on the academic component of the curriculum, there is consensus in favour of students acquiring

Column: 1866

a broader range of knowledge, and for greater emphasis to be given to critical process skills, such as thinking and innovative skills, the ability to make connections across subject disciplines, and communication skills.

    Second, there is considerable feedback that there should be adequate emphasis on the non-academic curriculum, so as to develop life skills and enhance the leadership qualities of our JC students. Employers, teachers and parents alike have emphasised the need to nurture strength of character, team spirit, enterprise, and a passion in what the students do. Whatever they choose to do, they must have passion.

    The Review Committee is studying various approaches to broaden the academic curriculum in JCs. One of these is a modular approach to the junior college curriculum, that will allow students to offer a core curriculum as well as electives in different areas. The elective subjects would be quite unlike the 'S' papers today, for instance, which drill deeper into subjects that students are taking at the "A" level. The broader JC curriculum could also be shaped to take into account what a student studies in his upper secondary years. All JC students would thus undergo a holistic programme of academic development over four years, in a range of subjects at their "O" and "A" levels, and at varying levels of difficulty. So as not to confuse Members, this is quite distinct from the issue of integrated schools, or through-train schools, which I will come to in a moment. The proposal I have just mentioned is one of those being studied for all JC students as part of the comprehensive review of the JC curriculum.
2.00 pm

    There is also support in the Review Committee and in our public consultations for retaining adequate depth in the JC curriculum. The main reason for this is that students have to pursue some subjects to a sufficient level of depth and difficulty in order to train their thinking skills and develop their powers of critical

Column: 1867

analysis. The traditional reasons for depth are also not irrelevant - the foundations that students acquire at JC in preparation for university cannot be too thin, particularly for those going on to pursue engineering and the sciences.

    The changes we introduce to the JC curriculum must therefore achieve an appropriate balance between breadth and depth of coverage, between content mastery and process skills, and between the academic and non-academic components of the curriculum. We must not compromise on the rigour of our JC curriculum. If we adopt a broader or more flexible curriculum, the learning process must remain demanding. We have to broaden the scope of the students' curriculum without lowering standards, the way it has turned out in some countries. But there will have to be trade-offs, so that we do not increase the overall load on students and teachers. There is no slack in our JCs, unlike the situation in the UK, for instance, before they introduced recent reforms requiring students to take more subjects at the "A" levels, or what they called "half-A levels". We cannot inject greater breadth without reducing the scope of content which students learn within the subjects they choose to specialise in. So there are trade-offs.

    The Review Committee is also studying whether we can achieve greater diversity in the structure of the upper secondary and JC education system, by allowing some schools to offer new pathways to a university education, new curricula and new assessment methods. We need this diversity in our system because there can be no single formula for preparing our young for an innovation-driven future - and an unpredictable future, a future which Mrs Yu-Foo described as "a change every day".

    In our public consultation sessions, there has been positive feedback on the case for specialised independent schools to develop students with special talents and abilities. For instance, an Arts School

Column: 1868

or a Mathematics and Science School, modelled along the lines of the Sports School, which will be operational in 2004. Dr Wang asked if such schools should not be run by the Ministry of Education. MOE will fund specialised independent schools in the same way it funds other independent schools. However, we prefer to have a specialised school run by a community that is willing to support the school and has an interest in its success, such as the arts community in the case of students with special talents in the arts. This is the best way of ensuring that there is demand for the school, and that the expertise, resources and energy of the community are brought to bear in the running of the school, not just initially but on a continuing basis. The community has to take ownership for the school to succeed.

    Another area that has attracted much discussion is the possibility of allowing some schools or Junior Colleges to offer integrated programmes, including both the upper secondary and JC level, within the same school. There is support in our public consultations for this proposal. Integrated programmes could be either four-year programmes beginning in Secondary 3, up to JC 2, or six-year programmes from Secondary 1 to JC 2. They can be offered by a single institution or by a family of institutions.

    One of the possibilities that is opened up by an integrated school is for some of its students - those who are confident of doing well in their "A" levels - to skip the "O" levels to free up time to develop their interests and for other broader educational experiences. We are also studying the possibility of allowing students in some schools to work towards different final qualifications, instead of the "A" levels. This could include allowing one or two schools to offer alternative programmes such as the International Baccalaureate, with appropriate local content.

    We have to accept that a more diverse education system, including new school structures or schools with different curricula, will carry with it a greater sense of differentiation. However, admission

Column: 1869

into such programmes has to be open, fair and meritocratic. Dr Wang raised the issue of whether the PSLE was an appropriate point at which students should be selected for integrated programmes leading up to JC. We are studying this carefully. There could be different points of entry for different schools offering integrated programmes, depending on how they structure their integrated programmes. One method being considered is for schools offering an integrated programme to admit students after the PSLE, as they currently do, and to assess after the lower secondary years, whether a student is suited to progressing on the integrated programme. Not all students in such schools will want to skip the "O" levels. The schools offering integrated programmes should also be able to take in a certain number of students at some point after the PSLE entry level. The school could do this by administering its own admission tests.

    As we consider freeing up the mainstream state-funded school system to allow for greater choice, the case for schools which are privately run and privately funded has been less compelling. Participants in the public consultation process have placed greater priority on the need for diversity within the state-funded system. However, the Review Committee has kept an open mind on the issue of private schools at this point. We are not ruling out the possibility of recommending that the Government allow for a few private schools who have a particular niche to serve, and who can provide an added source of ideas and innovative practices in education.

    Sir, to conclude, the review of the JC and upper secondary education system is an important part of MOE's efforts to meet future challenges. The Review Committee will put up a consultation document for further public comment in a few months' time, and make its final recommendations to the Government within five months.

    We are embarking on major innovations in our upper secondary and Junior College system. Any changes that the

Column: 1870

Government decides to adopt will have to be thought through in detail, and prepared for extensively. Teachers will have to be prepared, and will have to be confident of teaching any new curriculum well. A major change to the JC curriculum will take about five years to develop and implement. If we allow some schools to offer integrated programmes leading to Junior College, those that are conducted within the existing curriculum framework can take off within the next two years.

It is common perception that within the service, there is a distinction made between ---

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: Sir, I am indeed heartened by MOS Mr Tharman's enumeration of what is likely to come in the revised syllabus of tertiary students. I would like to take this opportunity though to elaborate on the important economic survival skills that our tertiary students must be equipped with, in order to give them that booster start when they enter their first career.

    There is no doubt that the educational institutions train and educate our students well in a broad range of subjects, from Mathematics to computing to the life sciences. This education equips our students with knowledge, skills and abilities which enable them to take up jobs in different sectors and thus contribute to

Column: 1871

the economic life of the nation. It seems to me, however, that there is a missing link. In as much as they are technically competent to take on employment, they are often relatively less well-prepared to transit into the wider work environment.

    By this I mean that graduates need, on the one hand, to have an awareness of trends and happenings in the wider socio-economic and cultural environment and, on the other hand, the ability or, at the very least, an understanding of what it takes to relate and interact with significant others in the workplace.

    For example, words like `globalisation', `the knowledge economy' and `continuous learning' are more than buzzwords - they have an impact on organisations and people who work in them. Do our students actually know what they mean, and what their significance is? How does the economic climate impact on jobs and careers and how should these changes be managed?

    In the workplace, for example, how may one conduct interpersonal relations effectively? How does one communicate with one's superiors, peers, subordinates, clients and suppliers? What does it take to work in a team? How does one motivate oneself and others? How does one deal with the `difference' in a workplace that has become increasingly diversified? And as we move to strengthen our service sector of the economy, how much do fresh graduates know about the management of emotions that is inherent in the nature of service work?

    All such knowledge constitutes competencies which can influence significantly individual and organisational performance. They also have a role to play in fostering creativity and an innovative frame of mind. On a larger scale, the possession of such competencies can constitute a competitive advantage.

    Now, it may be argued that, even without formal learning, employees do, in time, acquire such competencies relating

Column: 1872

to the wider environment and the conduct of interpersonal relations. I would contend however that rather than waiting for employees to acquire such competencies through what may be painful and costly trial-and-error experiences over time, we can shorten the learning curve considerably by inserting that learning into the curriculum of polytechnic and university graduates.

    I have in mind the institutionalisation of a course on the management of human relations in the polytechnic and university curriculum. Could the Minister kindly outline what measures his Ministry will take to prepare our graduates for this transition to the work environment in the knowledge economy?

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang: Sir, some Singaporeans still perceive Chinese to be dull and difficult to study, and the Chinese teachers to be rigid, inflexible and their teaching methods outdated and uninteresting. In fact, this has improved as new teaching methods were introduced, but image problems appear to persist. Today, more and more Chinese Language teachers, as what we understand, employ creative and lively teaching methods to cater to today's students.

    My key concern, however, is that MOE has set too many restrictions on the assessment of the subjects in primary and secondary schools. Some examples of irrelevant and outdated contents, such as standard letter-writing format, unrealistic composition topics, were still enforced by MOE and the schools.

    Sir, to enhance the effectiveness of teaching and learning, there is a need to review the assessment methods. For example, in many secondary schools today, "ciyu jieshi" is still a key component of test and CA for Chinese Language, which request the students to write out word by word from memory the meaning of the specific vocabulary. The way we set the test makes learning of Chinese as if memorising by heart the book of vocabulary. This has not only demoralised and made the learning of the Chinese Language tiresome but also

Column: 1873

hindered the ability of the students to learn the Chinese Language in a more creative and interesting way. Many students end up really hating the Chinese Language.

    Sir, today, we also have many principals sitting in the public gallery. I really hope the MOE and the school principals will consider this seriously. The examination and testing formats should be closely linked to the desirable learning outcomes. We need innovative ideas for teaching and learning, but, more importantly, we also need them for testing and assessment. Innovation in learning and teaching of the Chinese Language will not be effective without innovation in the assessment methods.

    Sir, the learning of mother tongue as a second language in our schools has been the subject of much contention, both within and outside this House.

    Presumably, the underlying principle of our second language policy is, among other things, to preserve our cultural heritage, since language is the vehicle by which values are transmitted from one generation to another. Sir, in my response during the debate on the President's Address earlier this year in this House, I had said that one major limitation of sending Singaporeans overseas lies in education. In particular, I believe that it is the learning of the second language that discourages many from going overseas to work. There is a genuine concern that when they return from their overseas posting or assignment, their children, having spent time overseas, may not be able to cope with the second language, especially if the posting is to a country that does not provide a proper environment for the learning of the second language. The consequence then is that for Singaporeans who invest overseas, it is difficult

Column: 1874

for them to find middle or top management to these places, usually it is these people who are the ones with school-going children.
2.15 pm

    To a point, the Government recognises this problem. I understand that the children of school-going age who spent sometime overseas are given some dispensation from learning the second language. For instance, a child who is absent from Singapore for some time need not offer a second language if he or she returns to Singapore in his PSLE year.

    Sir, in an extremely competitive environment, such as ours, I am not sure if such policies are sufficient to induce Singaporeans to go overseas. While the Ministry has been flexible in its second language policy, I feel that it does not go far enough. To begin with, it does not completely exempt the child from the requirements of the second language altogether. There could be situations where the child may be away too long for him to catch up with his language to a point where he is at a complete disadvantage to his peers. Does this mean therefore that he will perpetually labour under this disadvantage?

    Perhaps, the Government can do more. First, our Government should be prepared to be more flexible in the second language requirements if it is clear that the child is unlikely to, within the duration of his school career, effectively attain a measure of competence in the second language that will not put him at a distinct disadvantage with the rest. In such cases, the Ministry should allow perhaps the children the option of doing the second language at a more basic level, such as the CL 'B', as a way of easing the children into the language. Additionally, the Government should be prepared to back its high demands on the language requirements, by investing more resources in the teaching of the second language through the Internet. Sir, using the Internet has the distinct advantage of allowing people to log on to the site wherever they are. It is a

Column: 1875

virtual classroom that is not constrained by space and perhaps time. With multi-media capability, it would not be difficult for the child to pick up the language skills even in the spoken aspect of it. The Internet may therefore be used to update also the parents on the latest syllabus requirements.

    I believe that, to deal with the competing demands of second language and the need to send Singaporeans with young families overseas, we need not solve this by doing away with the requirement to learn the second language altogether. However, if the Government can be flexible in its demands and is prepared to invest more in Internet technology to assist in the learning of the language, I am sure it will go a long way towards encouraging Singaporeans to go overseas.

    Dr Ong Seh Hong(In Mandarin): Sir, let me tell a story. Once upon a time, a pack of wolves were living on a hill. There were black wolves, brown wolves and yellow wolves. At another hill nearby lived a group of monkeys, and they were gorgeous golden monkeys. Among this pack of wolves, there was one yellow wolf who did not like the colour of his fur, and he was also not happy with the sound of his howling. He aspired to become a golden monkey, like those living on the nearby hill. He therefore tried very hard to learn the cries of the monkeys, imitate their postures and even practised the way they climbed the trees.

    One day, he thought he had mastered the crying, walking and climbing skills of the monkeys, and decided to go to the other hill to join the monkeys as one of them. But, the moment the monkeys saw this wolf approaching, they surrounded him and attacked him. Fortunately for him, he managed to run away very quickly, but not before he sustained injuries all over his body. Dejectedly, he returned to the pack of wolves. But, when he opened his mouth, he had forgotten how to howl like a wolf, and found himself unable to blend into the pack of wolves.

Column: 1876



    The moral of this story is that no matter how well the yellow wolf had learnt the language of the monkeys, he should not neglect his own mother tongue, to howl like a wolf. Likewise, no matter how hard you have learnt to acquire proficiency in another language, you must not forget your own mother tongue.

    In his memoir, the Senior Minister mentioned that when he and his wife were studying in England, they met a group of Chinese students and from his interaction with them, he began to realise the extent of his cultural loss. He did not learn the Asian culture, and he did not belong to the English culture. He was lost somewhere between the two. For this reason, he subsequently sent all his children to the Chinese school to study their mother tongue.

    Another example is former NMP, Dr Lee Tsao Yuan. It was only after the age of 40 that she began to re-discover her own cultural roots. As such, we have a responsibility to help every citizen know and retain his own cultural heritage, and mother tongue is the important key to the preservation of cultural heritage. Therefore, we have a responsibility to help every one of our citizens maintain his own cultural heritage.

    Some people may say that you could also learn your own culture through the English language. Is that so? I personally feel that it is impossible for one to go deep into the quintessence of Chinese culture through English, and learn to appreciate the beauty of the Tang Dynasty poems. You cannot really understand your own language and your own culture through another language.

    Some people allege that mother tongue is the cause of racial segregation, and are fond of proposing that the mother tongue be abolished. They use incidents such as the September 11, the tudung, etc, as an excuse to advocate the scrapping of the SAP schools and the community-based self-help groups. Column: 1916

Government having to spend more on subsidies for MOE.     Sir, in the Addendum to the President's Address, the Ministry has declared its

Column: 1917

intention of taking greater control of the "A" level examinations in year 2002. It also floated the idea of setting up our very own Examinations Authority.
