    Mr Ong Ah Heng (Nee Soon Central)(In Mandarin): Sir, as we embark on the new high-tech knowledge-based economy in Singapore, we require not only many graduates from tertiary institutions, we also need highly-skilled technical officers so that all these technologies could be applied smoothly in Singapore.

Column: 1918

about it. They wanted their children to go to the mainstream schools. To them, those who were sent to ITE were those who could not make the grade to the mainstream schools. Given a choice, they would want their children to go to the mainstream schools, so that they could do their "O" level, "A" level and then go to the university.     I feel that the problem lies with the fact that many parents do not understand what prospects their children have when they go to ITE.     Secondly, if we want to instill more confidence in their parents, we should

Column: 1919

enhance the status of ITE. Our universities have linked up with other renowned foreign universities to become sister universities.     Mr Gan Kim Yong: Sir, I am not sure if we should thank Mr Jack Neo for thrusting ITE into the limelight with the film I Not Stupid because "it not good"!

    Sir, ITE plays a crucial role in providing the much-needed skills training, as well as continuous training. One good thing about the recession is that it reminds us that skills training is an integral part of our economic survival. As Singapore restructures our economy, there is an even greater need to increase the pool of skilled workers. Those who do not possess relevant skills will find it increasingly difficult to keep their jobs or find new jobs in time to come. The ITE produces more than 10,000 graduates a year, and many of them have done well. In fact, more than 1,400 of them

thereafter. This shows that ITE indeed is not the end.

    However, I feel compelled to remind ourselves that the success and the contribution of ITE should not be measured only by the number of graduates who proceeded to polytechnics or universities. We have also heard stories about ITE graduates being successful in business. ITE has, undoubtedly, done a good job. Its graduates are well regarded by their employers. Unfortunately, Sir, the image of ITE has been somewhat less than what it deserves, partly due to its association with its predecessor, the VITB, and partly due to the show I Not Stupid.

    I would like to ask the Minister whether he would consider putting in more resources into ITE to further expand and upgrade its programmes, as well as to have a proactive programme to improve its profile and image.     I hope that the Minister would also consider encouraging the ITE to have academic exchange programmes with reputable

Column: 1921

similar nature. This will undoubtedly inject greater professionalism into ITE. It will also help raise the international standing of ITE and boost its image. Then, we can change the image of ITE and it is no longer the end but to change it to the Institute of Technical Excellence.

    Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh)(In Malay): Sir, the Institute of Technical Education in our country has played an important role and will continue to play an important role in training our technicians and engineers for the future, our industry and the new economy. In our effort to remake Singapore, we should study skills upgrading programmes, retraining and lifelong learning for our workforce. The ITE and polytechnics will play an increasingly important role in this matter. The main challenge for the ITE and polytechnics is to attract and encourage our workers to return to school or the classroom.

    Sir, we often hear stories of outstanding ITE and polytechnic graduates who become successful entrepreneurs and businessmen. They bring pride to the ITE and polytechnics, and I feel more will achieve success. They make a name for themselves, thus bringing prestige to the institutions of ITE and the polytechnics through their success. Through their success, we will better appreciate the good efforts of these institutions that have prepared and equipped them for the employment market and the industrial world which are very challenging and competitive.

    Sir, ITE is one of the pillars of our education system. Both the ITE and polytechnic system emphasise excellence in technical education. Year after year, these institutions have undergone numerous renewals. Therefore, job opportunities for ITE and polytechnic graduates are good, and Singapore offers many opportunities for those who undergo technical education. We will see more new jobs and new potential in the knowledge-based economy. ITE and polytechnic graduates will find that they have a place for themselves

Column: 1922



    Sir, there are many areas in which the ITE and polytechnics can explore. The services industry has a large potential for them. Our nation is expanding the information technology, life sciences and chemical industries. These are areas which need a skilled workforce, and the ITE and the polytechnics could think of ways to support these thriving industries. Like other educational institutions, ITE and the polytechnics should encourage creativity and innovation. Their students should be given the freedom to explore and go deeper into their studies. Practical skills and certain skills are important, but they cannot ensure our survival. We should nurture our students with an entrepreneurial spirit and a "dare to fail" attitude so that they would work harder and face new challenges with success.

    The quality of technical education is high, and we are respected in many countries in the world. There are many examples where ITE graduates are successful in continuing their education to the university and polytechnic. This shows that the ITE has built a strong foundation and should be seen as a good beginning for our students. Technical training and the ability to "adapt oneself" for the ITE and polytechnic graduates are seen as two positive traits to nurture those who are technopreneurs. But ITE and the polytechnics can do more by offering additional business modules and giving support to the potential graduates through an incubation system and network of graduates. Technical education in our country has come a long way and will continue to expand. With new changes in the structure of ITE and polytechnics and also continuous upgrading of the staff and their facilities, these institutions will continue to excel. Our polytechnics have trained many people in this region. They appreciate our assistance and have praised the quality of the courses that we offer. Our neighbours in ASEAN have also benefitted. From one angle, we grapple with the effort to continue improving our products and services, but here we already have a good product, ie, the quality of our education and training. Outsiders see these as our brand name, but we have not reaped its full benefits.

Column: 1923

Why do we not market our educational services industry more aggressively? Sir, I propose that our main institutions can lead in this effort. We should not have the old thinking, ie, "Why should we help others to catch up or compete with us?" This is wrong because, if we do not improve on whatever we have, others will take over our place. Let us increase our effort to market our courses and services. Singapore can become the leading education centre in this region. I believe we can expand our services beyond the borders of Singapore.

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Sir, we have a strong and diverse post-secondary sector that caters to different types of students. Our ITE, polytechnics and universities offer Singaporeans access to an array of academic and technical options in further education.

    Sir, I would like to thank Mr Ong, Mr Gan and Mr Zainudin for the encouragement that they have given to ITE. We will continue to try and market ITE as well as we can. In fact, I would invite all Members of this House to come along, and I hope that they will come, including Mr Inderjit Singh, to see for themselves how well the students are doing.

    ITE has come a long way. It is now a confident, increasingly well-regarded post-secondary educational institution. The real success of ITE is not measured in terms of how many students have been able to go to polytechnic or how many students have gone on to university from ITE, although we celebrate the success of these students. The real success of ITE has been the fact that it has successfully raised the prospects and maximised the potential of young Singaporeans who, in other education systems all over the world, would have been left behind. The fact that youth unemployment in Singapore is not a problem, even in the middle of the recession, is evidence of the success of ITE.

    We have a robust polytechnic sector which provides vital technical and

Column: 1924

supervisory manpower, and many of our entrepreneurs and business leaders today come from the polytechnics. We have three good universities, each with their different and distinct focus and character. Different types of institutions, each with different missions and different emphasis, together, they provide a range of options to meet the needs of both the economy and individuals.

    Moving forward, we intend to expand opportunities and introduce greater diversity in the further education sector. We need to increase capacity so that all those able to benefit from further education can have access to our technical institutes, polytechnics and universities. We have significantly expanded opportunities across all types of post-secondary and tertiary education. Twenty years ago, less than three out of 10 pupils made it to post-secondary education. Ten years ago, it had grown to nearly six out of 10. Today, more than eight out of 10 do so. At the degree level, the Ministry is considering further expansion of the university sector. Our university cohort participation rate has quadrupled from 5% in 1980 to 21% today. With the sounder foundation that our students now receive in school, the university cohort participation rate can be raised from the current 21% to 25%, and we are now working to make this possible.

    Greater capacity is also necessary to provide for the larger cohorts of students feeding through to the post-secondary sector. As Members know, 1988 was a dragon year, with a bumper crop of 53,000 babies. In the 10 years following that, the number of babies born averaged 49,000, about 20% higher than the decade before 1988. These children started to come into the school system in 1995. In 2005, the dragon babies will be ready to enter ITE, the polytechnics and pre-university. We have anticipated this, and we will have sufficient places for them.
4.30 pm

    To achieve greater diversity and expand opportunities in the sector, the Ministry is currently restructuring ITE, building a fifth polytechnic and reviewing the university sector.

Column: 1925



    ITE will regroup its current 10 campuses into three Regional Campuses (RCs) over the next 15 years. The larger campuses will allow each campus to offer a full range of courses and provide the opportunities for cross-disciplinary training.

    $700 million will be spent to build a fifth polytechnic which will open its door in 2003. The Republic Polytechnic will not only increase capacity, it will inject greater diversity into this important sector of our education system, and help to further raise standards all round.

    An Inter-ministerial Committee, chaired by Dr Ng, is currently reviewing the university sector. He will update Members on this later.

    Let me now deal with specific issues on our public universities brought up by Dr Wang and Mr Yeo. I would first like to thank Mr Yeo for pointing out that NUS and NTU have achieved a degree of international standing for themselves. Both NUS and NTU aim for excellence in education, research and contribution to the community.

    Mr Yeo expressed concern on the impact of curricular broadening on the Department of Chinese Studies. I have been told by NUS that the emphasis on broad-based education does not preclude students from gaining a rigorous grounding in Chinese Literature, Chinese Language, history or philosophy. Students can still opt to read modules in both Chinese Studies and Chinese Language.

    Ultimately, a university will only flourish if they have capable and committed staff of high quality. Both NUS and NTU have put in place a market-driven performance-based renumeration system that gives them more flexibility to reward excellence and to attract and retain talent. Dr Wang and Mr Yeo have expressed some concern about the impact of these changes on staff. Sir, both universities are going through a period of transition from basically teaching-based institutions to institutions that place emphasis on both teaching and research. Some staff may adapt faster than others. However, I am

Column: 1926

confident that these changes are necessary for the success of the universities in the long-term. Dr Wang said that the staff attrition rate of NUS is high. Last year, 5.9% of NUS' faculty members or 116 left the university. This is not unreasonable, especially compared to the attrition rates of reputable universities worldwide, where the attrition rate of 10%, 12% or 15% is not uncommon. NUS has been able to successfully recruit new faculty members. Last year, NUS recruited 194 new faculty members. Too high a turnover rate, of course, is undesirable. But a certain level of turnover is healthy, if any organisation is to renew and regenerate itself. This turnover of faculty in NUS creates opportunities for intellectual renewal and ensures high academic standards, which is key to NUS' goal of being world-class.

    Our educational institutions must recruit the people strictly based on merit, and if Dr Wang has any evidence that this has not been so in any of our institutions, I would urge him to immediately make this known to my Ministry.

    Dr Wang spoke about universities switching to SAT. I would like to clarify that my Ministry has never said that SAT will replace the "A" levels. SAT I is only one component of the University Admission System and serves as a reasoning test that complements a content-based "A" level examinations. Having a basket of admission requirements provides for a more holistic measure of an applicant's ability.

    SAT II tests that Dr Wang mentioned are tests that measure specific content-based knowledge and would duplicate the function already served by the "A" levels. Hence, MOE has no intention to introduce SAT II. We will study what changes the College Board intends to make to SAT I, and see if it continues to be a test that suits our purpose. The establishment of an examination board does not reflect any second thoughts about SAT I.

    The intention of establishing an examination board is to build up our own capability and expertise in educational

Column: 1927

assessment and examination services. As Dr Wang pointed out, it will support our efforts to develop Singapore as an educational hub. The examination board will conduct the national examinations based on the Ministry's prescribed syllabuses and curriculum framework, and the Ministry would ensure that the examinations accurately assess pupils' achievement validly and reliably and are closely aligned to curricular objectives.

    Sir, examinations, testing and assessments are an integral part of the education process. They should not be seen as something separate. They provide feedback and ensure that standards are maintained. Examinations only become dysfunctional if they are not aligned with the objectives of education. If they measure things which are not really what your objectives are in education, it thereby leads students down a path which is not what you really want them to do. To reflect our focus on creativity and thinking, we have been modifying our examination formats to include open book examinations, source-based questions where students are required to draw inferences, project work, and school-based continuous assessment of the practical and experimental capability of our "A" level Science students. These are quite different from the traditional examinations and tests which students have taken in the past. Of course, they are more challenging for both the students and teachers to prepare for. Such assessments are more aligned with our educational goals.

    With our own examination board, we will be more able to ensure that examinations are well-aligned with our objectives, and that we can introduce innovations, such as IT-based assessments, without having to wait till others are ready.

    I will now ask Dr Ng to respond to the other points that Members have raised.

    The Minister of State for Education (Dr Ng Eng Hen): Mr Chairman, the Minister has sketched an overview of our post-secondary education sector. I would like

Column: 1928

to address specific queries from some Members. Let me touch on ITE and the polytechnic first.

    The Ministry wholeheartedly agrees with Mr Ong, Mr Gan and Mr Zainudin Nordin that the polytechnic and ITE sectors are important pillars of our education system. I would like to assure Members that the Government will continue to invest in technical education. For FY2002, the Government has budgeted $1.2 billion which translates to an increase of about 25% over FY2001's provision.

    The proposed FY2002 budget may give some Members, including Mr Gan, the impression that the Government is spending less. This is because in FY2001, the operating budget included a one-off payment for the outstanding GST on the polytechnics and ITE for prior years. Excluding this item, Government's spending for the technical education sector is actually significantly higher for FY2002. A fifth polytechnic will be developed and we will be spending more than $350 million in developmental costs to build ITE's first Regional Campus at Simei. The construction of the first Regional Campus will begin in the second half of this year.

    I am happy to note that Mr Ong Ah Heng and Mr Gan Kim Yong agree with the Ministry that ITE is an excellent institution. They feel that the ITE has been wrongly maligned and asked if we can do more to improve the public perception of ITE. I agree that ITE has been unfairly misrepresented. MOE is extremely proud of what ITE has accomplished. We consistently "show off" ITE to overseas guests who go away with great admiration and commend us for doing it right. What they mean is that we have resisted, in the words of Dr Amy Khor, trying to be "all things to all men". We have focused on substance, rather than form. We have done this because we assess correctly the abilities of that sector of the students, given them relevant value-added education and thereby help them find jobs and retain their dignity. Mr Ong Ah Heng can tell the parent, who was worried about her child who went to ITE, that not

Column: 1929

only is the moon very round, it is like a moon cake, you can taste the substance, with the yolk. The Minister has already reported that 88% of our ITE graduates find employment within three months of graduation. This is not not bad. This is very good. Hong Kong recently reported an unemployment rate of 14% for those aged 25 years and below, first time entering the job market. Many of these students went through the education system, but failed in so many subjects that they achieve neither substance nor form.

    Why do we get international praise for ITE whilst some locals perceive ITE negatively? Singaporeans will have to examine themselves to determine if they are making the correct value judgement. We will be proud, as my Minister says, to take them on a tour around ITE to help them make up their minds. But my ITE board, principals, teachers and students know full well my highest regard for them and their institution. More importantly, the teachers are proud to teach in ITE - they have a very low turnover rate. If the institution is bad, explain to me why the turnover rate is only 4%? They are proud despite the derision from some Singaporeans, many of whom have never visited ITE. These Singaporeans, by their unfair remarks, diminish the good work of committed teachers and the significant achievements of students in ITE.

    Thankfully, the majority of the public is more discerning and this has been helped by ITE's outreach programme. ITE indeed reaches out to 14,000 students in the Normal Stream and 1,800 parents annually. Special outreach programmes are also conducted for existing secondary school teachers and principals and the graduating trainee teachers at NIE, as they are significant groups of people who can advise students on their post-secondary educational choices.

    I am pleased to report that ITE's image has improved significantly in recent years. In an ITE public perception survey conducted in 1997, many Singaporeans felt that "ITE was good but not for me". However, in the 2000 survey, many people are now accepting that ITE does indeed

Column: 1930

provide an alternative and viable educational pathway which meets their career and academic aspirations. What is more encouraging is that 37% of respondents put ITE as one of their top three choices for post-secondary education.

    Let me now turn to the polytechnic sector. Mr Zainudin Nordin has asked if we should leverage on our reputation and strength to market services and products in quality technical education. Our institutions have already done that to a limited extent. I must, however, emphasise that marketing service overseas is not the primary mission of our polytechnics and ITE. Our polytechnics and ITE should continue to focus on providing accessible and quality technical education to Singaporeans.

    Sir, let me now speak about the university sector. I thank Dr Wang, Mr Iswaran and Dr Amy Khor for their interest in the Government's approach to expanding the capacity of the university sector. Both at the Inter-Ministry Committee and the ERC, we are fundamentally reviewing what roles the universities need to perform to continue to play an integral part in supporting our economic initiatives. This would be an opportune time to surface strategic issues regarding university education in Singapore.

    For brevity, I will simplify things by stating that the universities play three roles for Singaporeans. Firstly, they fulfil aspirations for those who want degrees. Secondly, they train and produce graduates to support our industries. Thirdly, they are incubators and "hatching grounds" for ideas that will lead and shape industry. We would have started on a very wrong footing if we approached the review mainly to fulfill aspirations - as Dr Amy Khor suggested, to give some people a second chance - of just deciding how to create an additional 3,000 more university places each year to accommodate 25% of our cohort of students. Governments in some European countries funded the expansion of their universities to cater to an ever-increasing pressure to allow more and more citizens to enter universities - and with

Column: 1931

diminishing returns. The idea is noble, well-intentioned but illusory: whoever seeks to be educated in whatever course shall be admitted. If the citizen is enriched through education, even if he does not have the academic ability required, then society is still enhanced. What happens? 30-50% of the first year cohort drop out; professors and lecturers become disheartened and demoralised. Standards drop, and the diminishing cycle perpetuates. Consider this. Despite 50% of the cohort in some European countries attending university, Europe is short of engineers (as told to me by Spanish, Danish industrialists and the UK Sterling Group of Professors)! So, too the United States. Let me quote to you what the Dean of Engineering at Tuft's University at Boston testified at the Capitol Hill last week. He said, "We have a severe shortage of engineers. We import engineers from abroad and a lot of our new technologies that we rely on for security reasons are developed abroad. And I don't think that's a safe path". Despite a dramatic increase in the country's demand for engineers, interest in the field has dropped significantly at colleges and universities nationwide. So this leading academician is now asking for more funds to reverse this trend. Even if he gets it, it will take some years for them to catch up.
4.45 pm

    Singapore has been more prudent and only funded students of sufficient calibre to enter our public universities and, more so, in particular disciplines of engineering and sciences that would help our overall economy. That policy of producing graduates relevant to industry enabled us to ride on globalisation and manufacturing in the last two decades and the economy thrived. This policy will continue but will not be enough to secure our future prosperity as we move up the value chain in a knowledge-intensive economy.

    China has a birth cohort of 24 million per year. Currently, they produce 1.6 million graduates, and that number will grow. In comparison, Singapore produces

Column: 1932

10,000 graduates each year from our public universities. We cannot compete on size or the average of our graduates alone. The "peaks", in other words, the highs that our universities and their graduates attain, must be our differentiating factor. Our universities must now move further up the value chain and have people who can create new knowledge and innovate. They must be able to effectively transfer this new knowledge into the business and industry, so that wealth creation will ensue. This is not something that we want but need to have for our economy to grow.

    The precious material in a knowledge-based economy is brain power, and investments will flow to wherever there is a concentration of this. The Research Triangle Park in the state of North Carolina, where Deputy Prime Minister Tan and I visited recently, clearly exemplifies that universities can create wealth for the country. The state of North Carolina has about eight million people. Forty years ago, its per capita income was the second lowest in the USA, only above the state of Mississippi. They were very much dependent on tobacco, textiles and agricultural industries with diminishing profits.

    The leaders from business, academia and industry, with the help from legislators, decided to start a research park based on their three leading universities - the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the North Carolina State University at Raleigh and the private Duke University. Today, the Research Triangle Park has achieved the wealth creation effect. Gross revenue generated last year was US$6.5 billion and the park provides work for 44,000 residents. The average incomes of the state have risen to be equivalent to the average income earned in the USA, and workers within the park earn 120% of the median income of workers within the USA. The average salary is about US$55,000 a year.

    This story of brains attracting investments is repeated across the USA and, indeed, much of the world, eg, the Oresund Region based in Sweden and

Column: 1933

Denmark. Some are planned more than others, but the elements of success are the same. Multi-national industrial corporations are moving away from their central laboratories to congregations of brains to mine for ideas. This creates wealth and it is a virtuous cycle.

    There are cogent lessons to be learnt. The first is that our universities must become engines of growth for our economy, not only just produce graduates to support the economy. All our public universities must find their niche in creating wealth. How can we help them do this? We can do so by matching capabilities with resources; allowing students and, indeed, faculties to move at the desired pace.
